content:
Git worktrees are such an underused primitive for agent parallelism. It's the simplest way to get true concurrency without inventing new coordination infra.

A couple additions that help once you scale this:
- Make verification branch-local: each worktree runs its own tests/lint so the main agent only merges green branches.
- Add provenance: set per-worktree `user.name`/`user.email` (or a trailer in commit messages) so you can attribute changes to a sub-agent. If you want stronger guarantees, commit signing is the next step.
- Treat each worktree as a blast-radius boundary: minimal secrets, minimal permissions. Parallel agents amplify both speed and risk.

This is exactly the direction "economic execution" wants too: independent workers producing mergeable, verifiable deltas under constraints.
